unnormalised: Today, we’re tackling everyone’s favourite (insert sarcastic tone here): algebra and equations. Specifically, we'll look at some common mistakes and how to avoid them. Think of it as a "get good at algebra" crash course.
normalised: Today, we’re tackling everyone’s favourite (insert sarcastic tone here): algebra and equations. Specifically, we'll look at some common mistakes and how to avoid them. Think of it as a "get good at algebra" crash course.

unnormalised: First off, remember BODMAS? Or PEMDAS, or whatever acronym your school uses. It's crucial! Forgetting to do brackets *first* can completely mess up your answer. Seriously. So, if you’ve got something like 2 x (3 + 5), do the (3 + 5) = 8 first, then multiply by 2. The final answer is 16. Not 2 x 3 + 5 = 11. See the difference? It is huge!!
normalised: First off, remember B-O-D-M-A-S? Or P-E-M-D-A-S, or whatever acronym your school uses. It's crucial! Forgetting to do brackets *first* can completely mess up your answer. Seriously. So, if you’ve got something like two multiplied by open bracket three plus five close bracket, do the open bracket three plus five close bracket equals eight first, then multiply by two. The final answer is sixteen. Not two multiplied by three plus five equals eleven. See the difference? It is huge!!

unnormalised: Next up: negative signs. They are sneaky little devils! Make sure you distribute them properly. A classic mistake is something like -(x + 3). A lot of people write -x + 3, which is *totally* wrong. It should be -x - 3. Remember, the negative sign applies to *everything* inside the brackets.
normalised: Next up: negative signs. They are sneaky little devils! Make sure you distribute them properly. A classic mistake is something like negative open bracket x plus three close bracket. A lot of people write negative x plus three, which is *totally* wrong. It should be negative x minus three. Remember, the negative sign applies to *everything* inside the brackets.

unnormalised: Solving for x? Great! But remember to do the same thing on *both* sides of the equation. If you add 5 to one side, you *have* to add 5 to the other side. Otherwise, the whole thing falls apart. It's like trying to balance a see-saw with two different weights – it just won't work. Also, if you get x = something crazy like 12345/6789, don't panic. It might be right! Always double-check your work, though.

unnormalised: And, final tip: practice! I know, I know, you're tired of hearing that. But seriously, the more problems you solve, the better you'll get. Start with the easy ones, then gradually move onto the harder stuff. Sites like Khan Academy are your friends. Also, remember that practice paper of the last year's IIT-JEE exam you saw? It will be of use.
